 You are correct that in the United States, the Supreme Court has ruled over time that rights are not absolute; they are to be balanced against a state interest in passing laws that may limit rights. But the state has to demonstrate, when challenged in court, that it in fact has a real interest, a rational basis at least, for the enactment of laws that deny people rights.
 
 You say that "rights have to be worked for." That's not the conception of rights that comes to us from Jefferson's Declaration of Independence, which he of course drew from the ideas of John Locke. Jefferson, and Locke before him, asserted that people have natural rights, given to us by the Creator, that are unalienable. It's certainly true that our U.S. society has backtracked a long way from recognizing rights as unalienable. Perhaps the principles in Jefferson's Declaration are just "glittering generalities" after all. But reasonable people can disagree over the source of rights, and how easily they may be taken away. 
 
 I think we are better off erring on the side of protecting individual rights and limiting the power of the state to infringe on those rights. Should the state have the power to deny same-sex couples the right to marry simply because a majority of people dislike the idea of same-sex marriage? I think not. People will get over their dislike of same-sex marriage, and it won't hurt them. Look at the example of Massachusetts, where polls indicate that a majority of state residents now support same-sex marriage. Having same-sex marriage legalized did no harm to opposite-sex marriages; it did no harm to anyone at all.  As to whether there is hatred "both ways," I can honestly say that I have never heard of any gay people who have tried to kill heterosexuals just because they are heterosexual, nor have I heard of any gay people who have sought to deny rights to heterosexuals. Perhaps there are some, but they are rare enough that I have never heard of them. Gay people do not murder heterosexuals for being heterosexual. Most heterosexuals do not murder gay people, but some do, and I can cite plenty of examples. Gay people do not beat up heterosexuals for being heterosexual. Most heterosexuals do not beat up gay people, but some so, and I can cite examples. I myself was beaten up some years ago after I walked out of a lesbian bar. I was attacked as I walked down the street, just because I had been in a lesbian bar. Fortunately, I was rescued by the police after a nearby resident phoned them. 
 
 It really is not accurate or fair to say that there is hatred "both ways." Gay people do not, except perhaps in rare instances, hate heterosexuals for being heterosexual. Gay people may hate those who practice oppression against them, but that's not the same as hating them for being heterosexual. In contrast, there are plenty of heterosexuals who hate gay people simply for being gay. Most do not, but there are still plenty who do. 
 
 You suggest that walking down the street holding hands, gay people encounter "distaste." Yeah, and we experience hatred too. Venomous hatred, and even threats and attacks, depending on where we happen to be. Try it. You don't know what it's like until you walk a mile in our shoes. Try living as an openly gay person for a year, and come back and tell us that we experience merely "distaste." See what it feels like. See what it's really like, not just what you imagine it is like. 
 
 I don't mean to sound confrontational here, but I am suggesting that you really don't know what gay people experience, and you really don't seem to grasp the level of fear that gay people have long had to live with. 
 
 Marriage has always been regarded as heterosexual? My answer to that is, "So what?" Discrimination against unpopular minorities has existed for a long time. That is not a reason to continue the discrimination. We now have same-sex marriage in a number of countries, and it has had no negative impact on heterosexuals or on those societies. 
 
 Is there any valid reason not to treat gay people as equals under the law? I can't think of any, and no one has presented any valid reasons. The only reason people seem able to muster is, "We have never allowed that in the past," and "We don't want to let gay people get married. The idea offends us." Those are not valid reasons to continue practicing discrimination, in my view.
